thread.title: Report: Airline cut PHL-Tel Aviv route to please Arab partners
thread.title_full: Report: Airline cut PHL-Tel Aviv route to please Arab partners

author: Jeff Blumenthal
title: Report: Airline cut PHL-Tel Aviv route to please Arab partners
text:
American Airlines image A report says American Airlines cancelled its daily Philadelphia to Tel Aviv route to… more American Airlines said last week that it was discontinuing its daily direct flights between Philadelphia and Tel Aviv in January because the route had yet to make money after six years. But Israeli newspaper Haaretz, citing anonymous sources in the aviation industry, said the real reason was the carrier’s ties to Arab airlines through its Oneworld alliance . “Profitability wasn’t a problem,” said an industry source, who asked not to be identified. “The past year hasn’t been easy for the airline industry in general, but that’s far from saying that the route wasn’t profitable. No one would have operated a money-losing route for so many years.” American made the decision due to the OneWorld global alliance, whose members include Arab carriers like Qatar Airways and Royal Jordanian and the carrier of the Muslim-majority Asian country Malaysia, asserted the source. Fla. tech firm deal brings dozens of jobs to South Jersey Haaretz said American has flown about 95,000 passengers on the route so far this year, an increase of 2.7 percent from the same time in 2014, according to Israel Airport Authority figures. American Airlines, however, said it lost $20 million on the route last year alone and it has not turned a profits on it since it began the route six years ago. A spokeswoman for the airline said last week that a number of factors determine the success of a route. “Load factor is not the only way, nor the best way to judge a route’s overall performance,” Victoria Lupica said. “We also look at overall demand and the fares customers are willing to pay on that route. In the case of PHL TLV, a number of factors have resulted in poor financial performance.” Bank cuts 280 positions in Center City When the service began in 2009, it was viewed as a sign of Philadelphia becoming more of an international hub for US Airways, which merged into American in 2013. The news comes at a time when Philadelphia officials are working feverishly to get more Israeli companies to pick Philadelphia as their U.S. headquarters location. Mayor Michael Nutter has made two trips to Israel — fall 2013 and last month — and at least five Israeli firms have agreed to open offices here. Nutter called American’s decision shortsighted. 
Get Philadelphia
